awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Collaborative Research: CoSeC-RAN: Cognitive Secure Cloud RAN for Efficient Spectrum Sharing
awd_abstract_narration:
Next generation wireless networks will be characterized by larger volume, faster information transfer, and diversity. Wireless industry has been altering conventional license-based spectrum access policies through approaches utilizing unlicensed spectrum. This leads to dynamic spectrum access (DSA), where unlicensed use of a spectrum should avoid harm to licensed users, or should ensure a fair share of spectrum with other unlicensed users. DSA places an additional burden on business operations because revenue needs to be generated over dynamically changing resources, while providing expected quality of service to potential users. Yet, existing high-level approaches for spectrum sharing are not well poised to solve the core problem. Instead, finer-scale spectrum sharing in time, space, and spectrum dimensions is required. Furthermore, at such finer scales, it is essential to consider human behaviors and integrate economics into the tool-set of spectrum sharing. Finally, recent cyber-security concerns necessitate that such a system should incorporate security and privacy in its core. This project designs and develops advanced spectrum sharing techniques at the nexus of spectrum, pricing, and privacy, for next-generation DSA solutions. The project is conducted by an interdisciplinary team of experts in security, operations management, decision science, wireless communication, networking, and optimization. The fundamental results emerging from this research can enable transformative cognitive radio network management and operation solutions. The project supports multiple graduate students. Insights from the proposed collaborative research project between Ohio State and University of Nebraska Lincoln will educate both industry and academia across rural Nebraska and urban Ohio regions.

The project explores four main goals: (1) Secure spectrum resource metering solutions with a Cognitive Secure Cloud Radio Access Networks (CoSeC-RAN) architecture. Preserving the digital base-band data within the network leads to more accurate resource assignment and pricing decisions. (2) Advanced security and privacy-preserving solutions. The novel CoSeC-RAN architecture enables new directions to provide security to and by the network while preserving user privacy. (3) Dynamic pricing algorithms, where prices are updated in real-time based on available capacity and customer load. These pricing algorithms reflect non-stationary and stochastic nature of both available capacity and demand. Customer-specific bandwidth requirements and mechanisms for ensuring customer privacy are incorporated into algorithm design. (4) Spectrum sensing methods with incomplete information. CoSeC-RAN estimates primary signals at secondary user locations, with incomplete information from the network, to ensure minimum interference. Developed solutions are rigorously tested through large-scale simulations and experimentally in a city-wide testbed.

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to design advanced spectrum-sharing tech for next-gen DSA solutions, exploring four goals: secure metering with CoSeC-RAN, advanced security/privacy, dynamic spectrum capacity sharing, and spectrum sensing with incomplete information. Solutions are tested through simulations and a city-wide testbed.

We analyze MIMO channel estimation using machine learning in spectrum sensing and find that a GRNN performs well compared to a known-channel communication. Up to 9dB improvement in SNR compared to LS channel estimation is observed, especially at low SNR. A complex-valued neural network for OFDM receivers in Rayleigh fading channels was designed using CCNN. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first CCNN used for radio design and the first to learn an OFDM receiver. The receiver performs physical layer functionalities while enhancing performance by exploiting waveform redundancy and learning channel statistics.

In addition, we study methods for efficient spectrum sensing and channel access with limited information. We use a multi-armed bandit framework to make decisions and address the issue of uncertain sensor abilities due to unknown shadow fading. Our proposed algorithm is based on an upper confidence bound for sensor selection, and a sample mean for channel access, resulting in sub-linear regret growth. We also study beam discovery in mmWave networks and propose a simple, energy-efficient transceiver architecture. We address the problem of beam alignment and user scheduling by posing it as a Markov decision process and derive a polynomial-complexity algorithm with a (1+ε) approximation of the optimal solution.

To study dynamic spectrum capacity sharing problems, we consider sharing between Wi-Fi and LTE-U in unlicensed spectrum systems on large university or industrial campuses. A Markov Decision Process model was built to make real-time capacity-sharing decisions with a secondary user and determine the optimal number of channels to lease for the primary user. In the MDP model, a leasing decision is made when the secondary users make a leasing request. An Approximate Dynamic Programming algorithm was also developed for the large state-space problem. We analyze the theoretical properties of the model and specify rules for leasing prices and slowdown fees. 

We study privacy issues in 802.11ac MU-MIMO and develop a novel eavesdropping technique called User Selective Eavesdropping (USE) Attack. To defend against USE, we introduce AngleSec, which detects malicious users with 91.9% accuracy in LoS and 84.7% accuracy in non-LoS environments. We also examine security in LTE and propose two attack models. We develop a secure prototype in NOMA wireless communications with improved weak user data rate (93%) and overall wireless users' weighted sum rate (36%). We also create a private and scalable geo-distance evaluation system to maintain privacy during RAN transfer to cloud endpoints, with private distance evaluation and improved runtime.

A city-wide gigabit wireless experimental testbed, the Nebraska Experimental Testbed of Things (NEXTT), is set up to evaluate research results using the CoSeC-RAN architecture with a common public radio interface over Ethernet. Deployed on seven sites, including indoor and agricultural locations, it has an interactive management and evaluation architecture. Experiments are conducted with devices from three vendors on a vast spectrum. Enabling researchers from five states to develop a web-based experimentation platform, NEXTT supports automated experimentation capabilities. 

We designed a continuous spectrum capture system using the NEXTT infrastructure. Our dataset spans multiple frequency bands over time, including TVWS, Cellular, and 900 MHz. Our design was validated with visualization techniques and aggregating real-time IQ samples from multiple radio endpoints. Since 2020, a distributed continuous spectrum sensing application collected over 140TB of over 11.9 million MHz-sec real-world data samples from three locations. Our system has been improved with the latest software and network settings to ensure smooth operation and a record-breaking amount of data collection suitable for machine learning applications.

The project offered hands-on learning to 80+ students in 7 course offerings, with students utilizing the platform during the pandemic. Undergraduate and graduate students used the USRP devices in the NEXTT testbed to learn wireless communications fundamentals. Some projects include collecting aircraft transponder signals, identifying mobile device locations, weather broadcast data, and more. The project findings were incorporated into OSU?s ECE6102 Wireless Networks course material. The remote teaching capabilities minimized the pandemic impacts on hands-on learning.

The project demonstrated results to VIPs such as  (U.S. Senator Fischer, FCC Chairman Pai, and stakeholders) via roundtable meetings and outreach events. Outreach events included Science Connectors showcases and a Raikes School Research Fair, reaching over 150 science teachers and undergraduate students. 

The associated resources (design, code, data) for the solutions and their evaluations have been stored following our data management plan. They are publicly shared on our software and datasets page (https://cpn.unl.edu/software- and-datasets) and the project page (https://cpn.unl.edu/projects/cosec) upon publication of research results.
